We continue to ask for patience and grace as we continue to navigate a new school year with added safety precautions and new learning options. Thank you!

Have a great weekend!

Any student in our district who qualifies for the Free/Reduced Lunch Program and has family members that are younger than 5 or are pregnant, breastfeeding or are postpartum less than 6 months, those family members would qualify for WIC.

WIC is an acronym for the Special Supplemental Nutrition Program for Women, Infants, and Children, which provides supplemental foods, health care referrals, and nutrition education for low-income pregnant, breastfeeding, and non-breastfeeding postpartum women, and to infants and children up to age five who are found to be at nutritional risk.

The WIC office is located in the Christian County Health Department on Brick Street in Ozark. Although the office is not open to the public at this time, they are conducting WIC appointments over the phone.Their phone number is (417) 581-2385 and business hours are 7:30-12:30, 1-4:30 Monday through Friday.

Sparta Community:

Earlier today, area leaders met to discuss COVID-19 and its impact on local school districts and communities. At that time, a decision was made to move forward with a 2-week extended school closure. This step is being taken to help ensure the health, safety, and well-being of our students and staff.

This closure will begin Monday, March 23rd and go through Friday, April 3rd. During this time, all school activities, including athletic and extracurricular practices and competitions, will be canceled.

The decision to close the district was extremely difficult, made in consultation with area superintendents, health department officials and out of an abundance of caution for our families.

As the week progresses, I will be sharing more information with our staff and community. Our immediate focus will be to provide food-service options to students starting next week. The administrative team will be working together in the coming days to develop our approach to the two-week closure.

Mr. Valentine

post_text: The Board of Education approved the 2020-21 District Calendar at the February 17th regular monthly meeting. We have a few changes this year: Due to new legislation, our start date can be no earlier than 10 calendar days prior to the first Monday in September. This will impact the start and end dates of the upcoming school years. The first day of school for the 20-21 school year will be August, 25th. This is about 10 days later than we normally get started. The district will no longer utilize early release Mondays, instead, we have strategically placed half days throughout the school year. This will allow for a consistent weekly schedule and increased instructional minutes for our teachers. The district’s final day of school will be slightly later than years past, but will not have any days added in May due to missed days from inclement weather.

Collaboration for the district’s strategic plan began in November 2019 with a dedicated group of 30 community leaders, students, parents, and staff coming together for the future of Sparta students. Working through our beliefs, mission, and vision for Sparta Schools, we produced a strategic plan to better our district for our students. Thank you to those who poured into this vision. The goals and strategies outlined in the Comprehensive School Improvement Plan will guide the district for the next five years. Our next step will be implementing these goals and communicating our progress to our stakeholders. We appreciate the community input that has led to this updated CSIP to help improve our school district.

To view the 2020-2025 Strategic Plan, visit our homepage under the District tab.
